lines.text: Enter MARIA and Clown

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: Nay, I prithee, put on this gown and this beard make him believe thou art Sir Topas the curate: do it quickly Ill call Sir Toby the whilst.
Exit

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Well, Ill put it on, and I will dissemble myself int and I would I were the first that ever dissembled in such a gown. I am not tall enough to become the function well, nor lean enough to be thought a good student but to be said an honest man and a good housekeeper goes as fairly as to say a careful man and a great scholar. The competitors enter.
Enter SIR TOBY BELCH and MARIA

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: Jove bless thee, master Parson.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Bonos dies, Sir Toby: for, as the old hermit of Prague, that never saw pen and ink, very wittily said to a niece of King Gorboduc, That that is is so I, being Master Parson, am Master Parson for, what is that but that, and is but is

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: To him, Sir Topas.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: What, ho, I say! peace in this prison!

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: The knave counterfeits well a good knave.

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: [Within]  Who calls there

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Sir Topas the curate, who comes to visit Malvolio the lunatic.

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: Sir Topas, Sir Topas, good Sir Topas, go to my lady.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Out, hyperbolical fiend! how vexest thou this man! talkest thou nothing but of ladies

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: Well said, Master Parson.

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: Sir Topas, never was man thus wronged: good Sir Topas, do not think I am mad: they have laid me here in hideous darkness.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Fie, thou dishonest Satan! I call thee by the most modest terms for I am one of those gentle ones that will use the devil himself with courtesy: sayest thou that house is dark

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: As hell, Sir Topas.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Why it hath bay windows transparent as barricadoes, and the clearstores toward the south north are as lustrous as ebony and yet complainest thou of obstruction

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: I am not mad, Sir Topas: I say to you, this house is dark.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Madman, thou errest: I say, there is no darkness but ignorance in which thou art more puzzled than the Egyptians in their fog.

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: I say, this house is as dark as ignorance, though ignorance were as dark as hell and I say, there was never man thus abused. I am no more mad than you are: make the trial of it in any constant question.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: What is the opinion of Pythagoras concerning wild fowl

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: That the soul of our grandam might haply inhabit a bird.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: What thinkest thou of his opinion

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: I think nobly of the soul, and no way approve his opinion.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Fare thee well. Remain thou still in darkness: thou shalt hold the opinion of Pythagoras ere I will allow of thy wits, and fear to kill a woodcock, lest thou dispossess the soul of thy grandam. Fare thee well.

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: Sir Topas, Sir Topas!

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: My most exquisite Sir Topas!

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Nay, I am for all waters.

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: Thou mightst have done this without thy beard and gown: he sees thee not.

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: To him in thine own voice, and bring me word how thou findest him: I would we were well rid of this knavery. If he may be conveniently delivered, I would he were, for I am now so far in offence with my niece that I cannot pursue with any safety this sport to the upshot. Come by and by to my chamber.
Exeunt SIR TOBY BELCH and MARIA

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: [Singing] Hey, Robin, jolly Robin, Tell me how thy lady does.

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: Fool!

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: My lady is unkind, perdy.

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: Fool!

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Alas, why is she so

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: Fool, I say!

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: She loves anotherWho calls, ha

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: Good fool, as ever thou wilt deserve well at my hand, help me to a candle, and pen, ink and paper: as I am a gentleman, I will live to be thankful to thee fort.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Master Malvolio

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: Ay, good fool.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Alas, sir, how fell you besides your five wits

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: Fool, there was never a man so notoriously abused: I am as well in my wits, fool, as thou art.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: But as well then you are mad indeed, if you be no better in your wits than a fool.

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: They have here propertied me keep me in darkness, send ministers to me, asses, and do all they can to face me out of my wits.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Advise you what you say the minister is here. Malvolio, Malvolio, thy wits the heavens restore! endeavour thyself to sleep, and leave thy vain bibble babble.

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: Sir Topas!

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Maintain no words with him, good fellow. Who, I, sir not I, sir. God be wi you, good Sir Topas. Merry, amen. I will, sir, I will.

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: Fool, fool, fool, I say!

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Alas, sir, be patient. What say you sir I am shent for speaking to you.

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: Good fool, help me to some light and some paper: I tell thee, I am as well in my wits as any man in Illyria.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Welladay that you were, sir

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: By this hand, I am. Good fool, some ink, paper and light and convey what I will set down to my lady: it shall advantage thee more than ever the bearing of letter did.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: I will help you tot. But tell me true, are you not mad indeed or do you but counterfeit

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: Believe me, I am not I tell thee true.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Nay, Ill neer believe a madman till I see his brains. I will fetch you light and paper and ink.

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: Fool, Ill requite it in the highest degree: I prithee, be gone.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: [Singing] I am gone, sir, And anon, sir, Ill be with you again, In a trice, Like to the old Vice, Your need to sustain Who, with dagger of lath, In his rage and his wrath, Cries, ah, ha! to the devil: Like a mad lad, Pare thy nails, dad Adieu, good man devil.
Exit
